project.readme: Security External Integrations planning board for releases, SDH, knowledge sharing, ON week, etc.
project.short_description: Security External Integrations planning board for releases, SDH, knowledge sharing, ON week, etc.
project.title: SEI Planning

content.body:
Our current Palo Alto NGFW integration supports the following log types:
- HIP Match
- Global Protect
- Threat
- Traffic
- User ID

However, several other log types are produced by Palo Alto and should be supported by us to ensure users are not left with blind spots across their Palo Alto logs, when using our integrations. Supporting these events, would also enable us to declare full support for PAN-OS 10 (including new fields added in v10). Details on log types can be found [here](https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/monitoring/use-syslog-for-monitoring/configure-syslog-monitoring.html). PAN-OS 10 fields will ned to be added to our current set of supported log types listed above also. The list of types we need to add for support are as follows:
- Authentication
- Config
- Correlated Events
- Decryption
- GTP
- IP Tag
- SCTP
- System
- Tunnel Inspection
content.title: Palo Alto Firewalls | Supporting All Log Types

provided.title: Palo Alto Firewalls | Supporting All Log Types

project.readme: Security External Integrations planning board for releases, SDH, knowledge sharing, ON week, etc.
project.short_description: Security External Integrations planning board for releases, SDH, knowledge sharing, ON week, etc.
project.title: SEI Planning

content.body:
Based on feedback from Github directly, they recommend that we add support for some additional security events within the Github integration. These events are:

- [Code Scanning](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/code-scanning)
- [Dependabot](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/dependabot)
- [Secret Scanning](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/rest/secret-scanning)

We should aim to support both polling the API via the httpjson input and receiving [webhook callbacks](https://docs.github.com/en/developers/webhooks-and-events/webhooks/creating-webhooks) via the http_endpoint input. They both have their pros and cons. Ideally we can create one data stream for each such that we support audit, code_scanning, dependabot, and secret_scanning. And each of those has two input sources -- webhook or API polling.
content.title: Github Advanced Security
